Do you think that having a habitable planet orbiting a brown dwarf is possible if it orbits really close to the star? So in that case most of the planets would probably be huddled up next to their star, And since the mass a brown dwarf is low the DeltaV required to get from one planet to the other would not be much.

They do exist. They have been observed. And despite their name the light they give off (by wavelength analyzing) is magenta.

A brown dwarf would probably look like a really hot jupiter, And if you turn on your stove then you will notice it starts to turn red, The color of a star depends on heat, And since a brown dwarf is just barely hot enough to even glow, It probably glows a dark red.

It likely depends on the type of brown dwarf. the hotter, M-types likely glow dull reddish-brown, cooler Y-types magenta.

(may have gotten that backwards)

> 
> A brown dwarf would probably look like a really hot jupiter, And if you turn on your stove then you will notice it starts to turn red, The color of a star depends on heat, And since a brown dwarf is just barely hot enough to even glow, It probably glows a dark red.

Then why is it magenta? Because it's Deuterium fusing, not hydrogen. And there's not much of it. So, it most likely heats up the gas giant material it's comprised of, which is dependent on a lot of things.

But most pictures, like the ones from Spitzer Telescope, have magenta brown dwarfs.
